heading.title: PART 7 PARTIES TO PROCEEDINGS AND REPRESENTATION [rr 7.1–7.42]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 7 PARTIES TO PROCEEDINGS AND REPRESENTATION [rr 7.1–7.42]

row.entry: This Division permits individuals, corporations and authorised company directors to commence proceedings. It requires unrepresented parties to obtain leave to issue subpoenas.

The rules in this Division permit representative proceedings in various situations, including proceedings affecting a deceased, or trust, estate and other proceedings in which many people have the same interest.

entry.emph: Division 3 — Executors, administrators and trustees — Rules 7.11 –7.12

row.entry: This Division requires the joinder of all executors, administrators and trustees in any proceedings related to their functions and property.

entry.emph: Division 4 — Persons under legal incapacity — Rules 7.13–7.18

row.entry: This Division requires the appointment and removal of tutors where the proceedings are conducted on behalf of persons under legal incapacity. It sets out a tutor’s obligations when commencing proceedings, and precludes default judgment being entered against a person under legal incapacity.

This Division sets out the procedure for commencing proceedings against a person operating under an unregistered business name. It requires contested proceedings to be conducted in the proper name of the defendant.
This rule requires a relator (person undertaking proceedings with the approval of the Attorney-General) to be represented by a solicitor.

entry.emph: Division 7 — Appointment and removal of solicitors — Rules 7.24–7.31

row.entry: This Division governs the appointment, change, withdrawal and removal of solicitors. It includes the procedural requirements of notifying a change in representation.

entry.emph: Division 8 — Commencement of proceedings under particular Acts

row.entry: This Division permits certain proceedings under the Confiscation of Proceeds of Crimes Act 1989 to be commenced and carried on in the Local Court by a police prosecutor.

entry.emph: Division 9 — Court appointed referral for legal assistance

row.entry: This Division permits the court by order to refer a litigant to the registrar for referral to a barrister or solicitor on the pro bono panel for legal assistance.
This Part applies to all courts in Sch 1 of the CPA except Divs 2 and 6. Those Divisions do not apply to the Local Court, Small Claims Division: see r 1.5 and Sch 1.

All the rules in this Part derive from, and reproduce without significant change, the former SCR Pts 8, 63, 64, 66, 66A and 68. Similar provisions were contained in DCR Pts 7, 28C, 45, 46 and 48 and LCR Pts 6, 34, 35 and 37. Division 8 was added by UCPR Am 19 2007. Division 9 was added by UCPR Am 23 2008.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 7.1] r 7.1 By whom proceedings may be commenced and carried on (cf SCR Part 4, rules 4 and 4A, Part 66, rule 1; Act No 9 1973, section 43; Act No 11 1970, section 11)

leg:heading.title: By whom proceedings may be commenced and carried on (cf SCR Part 4, rules 4 and 4A, Part 66, rule 1; Act No 9 1973, section 43; Act No 11 1970, section 11)

p.text: A natural person may commence and carry on proceedings in any court, either by a solicitor acting on his or her behalf or in person.

Despite subrule (1), but subject to subrule (5) , the court may order that proceedings commenced by a natural person acting on behalf of another person pursuant to a power of attorney be carried on, on behalf of that other person, by a solicitor.
[subr (1A) insrt Amendment 29 of 2009 Sch 1[4], effective 8 October 2009]
A company within the meaning of the Corporations Act 2001 of the Commonwealth:
may commence and carry on proceedings in any court by a solicitor or by a director of the company, and
may commence and, unless the court orders otherwise, carry on proceedings in the Local Court by a duly authorised officer or employee of the company.
[subr (2) am Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 2[1], effective 6 July 2009]
In the case of proceedings in the Supreme Court, subrule (2)(a) authorises a company to commence proceedings by a director only if the director is also a plaintiff in the proceedings.
A corporation (other than a company within the meaning of the Corporations Act 2001 of the Commonwealth):
may commence and carry on proceedings in any court by a solicitor, and
may commence and carry on proceedings in any court (other than the Local Court) by a duly authorised officer of the corporation, and
may commence and, unless the court orders otherwise, carry on proceedings in the Local Court by a duly authorised officer or employee of the corporation.
[subr (4) am Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 2[1], effective 6 July 2009]

Despite subrules (1)–(4), any person may commence and, unless the Commission orders otherwise, carry on proceedings in the Industrial Relations Commission by an industrial agent within the meaning of the Industrial Relations Act 1996.
[subr (4A) insrt Amendment 31 of 2009 Sch 1[2], effective 1 February 2010]
Subrule (4A) does not apply to or in respect of proceedings in the Industrial Relations Commission when constituted as the Industrial Court.
[subr (4A) insrt Amendment 31 of 2009 Sch 1[2], effective 1 February 2010]
Despite subrules (1)–(4), any person may commence and, unless the court orders otherwise, carry on proceedings in the Local Court:
by a commercial agent with respect to debt collection (within the meaning of the Commercial Agents and Private Inquiry Agents Act 2004), in relation only to proceedings on an application for:
an instalment order, or
an order for examination, or
a writ of execution, or
a garnishee order, or

by a person holding a licence as a real estate agent, strata managing agent or on-site residential property manager within the meaning of the Property, Stock and Business Agents Act 2002 in relation only to:
proceedings on an application referred to in paragraph (a), or
the filing of a certificate under section 51 of the Consumer, Trader and Tenancy Tribunal Act 2001.
[subr (5) am Amendment 9 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 9 June 2006 ; am Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 2[1], effective 6 July 2009]
A solicitor who is a person’s solicitor on the record must hold an unrestricted practising certificate.
The term solicitor on the record is defined in the Dictionary.
[subr (6) insrt Amendment 24 of 2009 r 2 and Sch 1[8], effective 6 March 2009]
Legislation cited in [7.1.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 60.

Generally, the public interest in the efficient and proper conduct of litigation requires that the presentation of the opposing cases be made by properly qualified practitioners upon whom the court is entitled to rely to conform to the general standards of professional competence and probity: Abse v Smith [1986] QB 536; [1986] 1 All ER 350 ; Teese v State Bank of New South Wales [2002] NSWCA 219; BC200203807 . However, notwithstanding subr (1), a judge may grant leave to any person to appear on behalf of a litigant: O'Toole v Scott [1965] AC 939 at 952; [1966] ALR 821 ; Hubbard Association of Scientologists International v Anderson [1972] VR 340 at 343 ; Ex parte Browne (1913) 13 SR (NSW) 593 at 601; 30 WN (NSW) 194 (solicitor's managing clerk); Charles P Kinnell & Co Ltd v Harding Wace & Co [1918] 1 KB 405 at 413 . Examples of the exercise of the discretion include Galladin Pty Ltd v Ainsworth Pty Ltd (1993) 60 SASR 145 (co-defendants with common interests — legally aided representation withdrawn during the course of the hearing); Schagen v The Queen (1993) 8 WAR 410; 65 A Crim R 500 (hearing impaired litigant — legal aid refused). Examples can also be found in various English authorities where non-barristers have been permitted to appear in the High Court: Doxford & Sons Ltd v Sea Shipping Co Ltd (1897) 14 TLR 111 ; Butterworth v Butterworth (1913) 57 SJ 266 ; Engineers' & Managers' Assn v Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service [1979] 3 All ER 223; [1979] 1 WLR 1113 ; Abse v Smith [1986] QB 536; [1986] 1 All ER 350 . However, it is usually undesirable that leave be given: Giniotis v Gaidzionis (1985) NSWJB 224; Damjanovic v Maley (2002) 55 NSWLR 149; 195 ALR 256; [2002] NSWCA 230; BC200203991 (leave refused); Teese v State Bank of New South Wales [2002] NSWCA 219; BC200203807 at [5]–[6] and [10]–[13]; Portelli v Goh [2002] NSWSC 997; BC200206745 (refusal to allow a litigant’s friend appear in the Local Court); JP Morgan Trust Australia Ltd v Hammond [2012] NSWSC 213; BC201201252 (application by defendant’s husband for leave to appear for her as lay advocate at final hearing refused — conflict of interest, no duty owed to court or opponent). Leave ought ordinarily be regarded “as a reserve or occasional expedient, for use primarily in emergency situations when counsel is not available, or in straightforward matters where the assistance of counsel is not needed by the court, or where it would be unduly technical or burdensome to insist on counsel”: Re GJ Mannix Ltd [1984] 1 NZLR 309 at 314 ; Scotts Head Developments Pty Ltd v Pallisar Pty Ltd (NSWCA, Full Court, 6 September 1994, unreported, BC9402965) per Mahoney AP. A litigant's mere aversion to lawyers is not a sufficient basis for granting leave: Teese v State Bank of New South Wales [2002] NSWCA 219; BC200203807 . However, in Scotts Head Developments Pty Ltd v Pallisar Pty Ltd , above, Mahoney JA noted that in courts of limited jurisdiction, a greater degree of flexibility existed. The courts’ requirement to consider the proportionality of costs (see CPA s 60 ) may encourage continued flexibility.

p.text: Legislation cited in [7.1.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 7.1(2)(a), r 7.1(3), r 7.2, 232, ss 233(1)(g).
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 14.

heading.title: Proceedings by or against corporations — Corporations Act 2001

p.text: The present rule applies to the conduct of proceedings on behalf of the company and, by virtue of UCPR r 7.2 , requires evidence of the person’s authority to act on the company’s behalf: see further [7.2.5] and [7.2.10] .

The right or ability of a company to commence Supreme Court proceedings by a director is, qualified. UCPR r 7.1(3) makes eligible, for the purposes of UCPR r 7.1(2)(a) only a director who is, in their own right, a plaintiff in the proceedings. The combined effect of UCPR rr 7.1(2)(a) and 7.1(3) is that, if the company and a director of the company are both plaintiffs, the company may commence and carry on the proceedings by that director: JSBG Developments Pty Ltd v Kozlowski (2009) 75 NSWLR 745; 236 FLR 288; [2009] NSWSC 1128; BC200909671 at [18] per Barrett J. The rule does not thereby allow a director who has been named as a plaintiff to continue as a plaintiff in the absence of that director having a proper personal cause of action against the defendant: Connectland Pty Ltd v Porthaven Pty Ltd [2011] NSWSC 616; BC201104687 at [18]–[19] per White J; Tanamerah Estates Pty Ltd v Tibra Capital Pty Ltd [2013] NSWSC 36; BC201300376 at [98]–[99] per Hallen J. However, the court could dispense with these requirements of the rules pursuant to s 14 Civil Procedure Act 2005: Connectland Pty Ltd v Porthaven Pty Ltd, above at [19] per White J; Access Services Group Pty Ltd v McLoughlin (2006) 201 FLR 16; (2006) 57 ACSR 725; [2006] NSWSC 532; BC200604077 at [12] per Barrett J.
Apart from the present rule, several provisions of the Corporations Act 2001 provide for situations in which persons may be permitted to conduct proceedings “on behalf of” a company.

The Supreme Court may authorise a member to sue in the name of and on behalf of a company where its affairs are being conducted in a manner that is oppressive, unfairly prejudicial to, or unfairly discriminatory against, a member or in a manner that is contrary to the interests of members as a whole: ss 233(1)(g) and 232 ; Fexuto Pty Ltd v Bosnjak Holdings Pty Ltd (2001) 37 ACSR 672; 19 ACLC 856; [2001] NSWCA 97; BC200101720 . For discussion of member’s derivative actions under the Corporations Act 2001 see Ford’s Principles of Corporations Law at [11.239]–[11.300]. The relationship between the operation of s 233(1)(g) and Pt 2F.1A is discussed at [11.275].

heading.title: Corporations Act: Part 2F.1A — inaction by the company:

p.text: The Supreme Court may grant leave to any member, former member, or person entitled to be registered as a member of a company or a related body corporate, and any officer or former officer of a company, to bring proceedings in the name of the company, or intervene in any proceedings to which the company is a party for the purpose of taking responsibility on behalf of the company for those proceedings, or for a particular step in those proceedings (eg compromising or settling them): see ss 236(1) , 236(2) and 237(1) of the Corporations Act 2001.
An applicant for leave must satisfy the court of the five criteria set out in s 237(2) : Re Varsity Queensland Pty Ltd (2006) 60 ACSR 366; [2006] QSC 356; BC200610008 . Those criteria are:
inaction by company: see Carpenter v Pioneer Park Pty Ltd (2004) 211 ALR 457; 51 ACSR 299; [2004] NSWSC 1007; BC200407193 ;

good faith in desiring to participate in the proceedings: Goozee v Graphic World Group Holdings Pty Ltd (2002) 170 FLR 451; 42 ACSR 534; [2002] NSWSC 640; BC200204083 ; Fiduciary Ltd v Morningstar Research Pty Ltd (2005) 53 ACSR 732; 23 ACLC 1100; [2005] NSWSC 442; BC200502971 at [15] ;
that granting leave is in the best interests of the company: Swansson v RA Pratt Properties Pty Ltd (2002) 42 ACSR 313; 20 ACLC 1594; [2002] NSWSC 583; BC200203661 at [24] ;

that there is a serious question to be determined in the proceedings: Swansson v RA Pratt Properties Pty Ltd (2002) 42 ACSR 313; 20 ACLC 1594; [2002] NSWSC 583; BC200203661 at [25] per Palmer J; Reale v Duncan Reale Pty Ltd [2005] NSWSC 174; BC200501950 at [11] (complete deadlock — leave granted); Goozee v Graphic World Group Holdings Pty Ltd (2002) 170 FLR 451; 42 ACSR 534; [2002] NSWSC 640; BC200204083 at [33] and [34] per Barret J (no evidence against proposed defendant — leave refused);
the company has been given, or it is appropriate to dispense with, written notice of the application.

Leave cannot be granted under s 237 of the Corporations Act where the company is in liquidation: Chahwan v Euphoric Pty Ltd (2008) 245 ALR 780; 227 FLR 43; [2008] NSWCA 52; BC200802354 . But despite s 236(3) of the Corporations Act, the Supreme Court retains its inherent power to permit a person to represent the interests of a company in appropriate circumstances: see [7.1.12] below.

In proceedings under the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth), the court has power under Corporations Law Rules 2000 r 2.13 to grant leave to a creditor, contributory or officer of a corporation to be heard without becoming a party to the proceedings. Alternatively, the court may join such a person as a defendant to the proceedings. An appropriate occasion for leave or joinder may arise, for example, in winding-up proceedings where an officer of the corporation wishes to oppose the winding-up order; there is apparent substance in the defence proposed; and the withholding of leave will have the practical effect of preventing the defence from being considered: Commonwealth Bank of Australia v Western D Engineering Co Pty Ltd (NSWSC, McLelland CJ in Eq, No 1548/93, 8 August 1994, unreported, BC9402922).

heading.title: Civil Procedure Act 2005 and inherent jurisdiction

p.text: CPA s 61 and Supreme Court Act 1970 s 23 may also confer a discretionary power to permit a person to represent the interest of a company in proceedings, even where the criteria provided for in ss 236 and 237 of the Corporations Act 2001 have not been satisfied: Hawkesford v Hawkesford (2006) 61 ACSR 27; [2006]NSWSC 1458; BC200611127 at [26]–[42] per White J. Even though s 236(3) of the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) abolishes “the right of a person at general law” to pursue proceedings on behalf of a company, that provision does not restrict a court, as an incident of its control of the particular proceedings before it, from granting leave to any person to represent the company: Chahwan v Euphoric Pty Ltd (2008) 245 ALR 780; 227 FLR 43; [2008] NSWCA 52; BC200802354 at [124](j); Ragless v IPA Holdings Pty Ltd (in liq) (2008) 65 ACSR 700; 26 ACLC 404; [2008] SASC 90; BC200802409 at [44]; Syndicate Mortgage Solutions Pty Ltd v El-Sayed [2010] NSWSC 348; BC201002474 at [10] and [11] (leave granted subject to indemnifying the company in liquidation). The occasions for the exercise of the discretion should properly be regarded as exceptional: see [7.1.5] above.

(NSW) Legal Profession Act 2004 s 4, s 54, s 87.

Section 87 of the Legal Profession Act 2004, like its predecessor in s 38L of the 1987 Act, grants rights of audience in any court to any barrister or solicitor. Those terms are defined to include any legal practitioner who holds an applicable practising certificate: see s 4 of the 2004 Act; and does not differentiate between the holders of restricted and unrestricted certificates. Consequently employed solicitors ( s 54 of the Act requires barristers to be sole practitioners) derive a right of audience from this section, irrespective of whether or not their practising certificates are subject to a condition requiring supervision: Adler Mallach Holdings Pty Ltd v Robertson [2002] NSWSC 998; BC200206408 (which deals with s 38L of the 1987 Act). The right of audience conferred by section 87 (and its predecessors) alters the view that been taken under earlier versions of the statutory right of audience. Until the enactment of s 18 of the Legal Profession Act 1987, the term “solicitor” was taken to refer only to a solicitor with a full practising certificate. It was thought not to include an employed solicitor or a solicitor’s managing clerk: Garrett v Phillips (1909) 26 WN (NSW) 79a ; Ex parte Browne (1913) 13 SR (NSW) 593; 30 WN (NSW) 194 ; Re Lemme (1928) 45 WN (NSW) 172 ; Re Bannister (1975) 5 ACTR 100 . Consequently only the solicitor on the record and their partner was recognised as having a right of audience. Employed solicitors could only appear by leave: Beaton v McDivitt (1985) 13 NSWLR 134 at 160 ; although the apparent formality of this limitation was substantially ameliorated by a long history of according solicitors’ managing clerks a right of audience before masters (ie, associate Judges) and registrars: Ex parte Browne, above, at 601.

level.toc-caption: [7.1.20] Litigants in person: assistance of an interpreter

heading.title: Litigants in person: assistance of an interpreter

p.text: The court may allow a litigant in person to address the court through an interpreter: Re Trepca Mines Ltd [1959] 3 All ER 798; [1960] 1 WLR 24.

level.toc-caption: [7.1.25] Litigants in person: assistance by the court

heading.title: Litigants in person: assistance by the court

p.text: The fair and impartial conduct of proceedings requires the parties to be adequately informed about the respective rights and responsibilities. Where a party is unrepresented the court itself ought to ensure, so far as reasonably practicable, that the unrepresented party has sufficient information about the practice and procedure of the court to preserve the fairness of the proceedings: Hamod v NSW [2011] NSWCA 375; BC201110561 at [309]–[316] . But the court should provide that kind of informational assistance to an unrepresented litigant without thereby conferring any advantage over legally represented opponents: MacPherson v R (1981) 147 CLR 512; 37 ALR 81; 55 ALJR 594; BC8100115 ; Rajski v Scitec Corp Pty Ltd (NSWCA, Kirby P, Samuels and Mahoney JJA, 16 June 1986, unreported, BC8600928); see also Minogue v Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (1999) 84 FCR 438; 166 ALR 129; [1999] FCA 85; BC9900296 .

This dual responsibility — to provide necessary information whilst remaining objectively and actually impartial, gives rise to a difficult problem, upon which judges have frequently remarked, of providing necessary assistance to one litigant without generating either the appearance or the actual risk of partiality: Titan v Babic (1994) 49 FCR 546 at 554–5; 126 ALR 455; BC9406522 ; Re Morton; Ex parte Mitchell Products Pty Ltd (1996) 21 ACSR 497 at 513–14; BC9604433 ; Tardy v Secretary, Dept of Community Services and Health (NSWSC, McLelland J, 9 October 1990, unreported, BC9001906); Re Hunter; Ex parte Webb (FCA, Sheppard J, No 994/96, 19 July 1996, unreported, BC9604062); Reisner v Bratt [2004] NSWCA 22; BC200400893 (judge’s task); Malouf v Malouf (2006) 65 NSWLR 449; [2006] NSWCA 83; BC200602697 at [94] and [100] per Mason P, [183] per Bryson J; McMurtrie v Commonwealth [2006] NSWCA 148; BC200604387 at [46] and [49]; Paramasivam v University of New South Wales [2006] NSWSC 1189; BC200609201 at [19] and [21] (litigant in person had strong feelings of grievance against opposing party).

The proper extent of a judge's assistance and intervention cannot be precisely defined: Minogue, above, at [28]; Re F (Litigants in Person Guidelines) (2001) 161 FLR 189; 27 Fam LR 517; (2001) FLC 93-072; [2001] FamCA 348 at [228] ff. It must necessarily depend on the particular case and the capacity of the unrepresented litigant's: Abram v Bank of New Zealand [1996] ATPR 41-507; BC9603410 . A court is not required to assist unrepresented litigants formulate questions in admissible form: R v Zorad (1990) 19 NSWLR 91; 47 A Crim R 211 . But the tender of potentially inadmissible evidence by an opposing party may be an occasion where the court should intervene and attribute an objection to the unrepresented party: National Australia Bank Ltd v Rusu (1999) 47 NSWLR 309; [1999] NSWSC 539; BC9902958 (non-English speaking litigants in person); cf Marriage of Johnson (1997) 139 FLR 384; 22 Fam LR 141; (1997) FLC 92-764 .

If a litigant in person lacks the competence to conduct their own affairs, the court ought to appoint a tutor: Murphy v Doman (2003) 58 NSWLR 51; [2003] NSWCA 249; BC200305305 . If a litigant in person refuses to continue the proceedings (eg in protest against an interlocutory ruling) the Court may dismiss the proceedings, but should not do so without first informing the litigant of their potential costs liability: Jeray v Blue Mountains City Council (No 2) (2010) 180 LGERA 1; [2010] NSWCA 367; BC201009842 at [24]–[31] .

The Full Court of the Family Court has set out “guidelines” for Family Court judges when hearing cases involving unrepresented litigants: In the Marriage of Johnson (1997) 139 FLR 384; 22 Fam LR 141; (1997) FLC 92-764 at [121] and re-formulated in Re F (Litigants in Person Guidelines) (2001) 161 FLR 189; 27 Fam LR 517; (2001) FLC 93-072; [2001] FamCA 348 at [253] . These guidelines have particular relevance to the family jurisdiction where the interests of (unrepresented) children must be taken into account.

A represented party may itself have obligations to assist the court in relation to the conduct of proceedings by a self-represented litigant: Serobian v Commonwealth Bank of Australia [2010] NSWCA 181; BC201005651 at [42] per Macfarlan JA (a competently represented party, especially where the party is itself an experienced litigant, must assist the court to understand and give full and fair consideration to the submissions of the litigants in person).

level.toc-caption: [7.1.30] Litigants in person: assistance by McKenzie friend

heading.title: Litigants in person: assistance by McKenzie friend

p.text: Short of such an exceptional situation, and apart from permissible curial assistance, unrepresented litigants may be assisted in court by friends who are there to assist and advise them in their conduct of the case, including suggestions about the calling and cross examination of witnesses: McKenzie v McKenzie [1971] P 33 [1970] 3 All ER 1034. The McKenzie friend's only role is to provide the litigant with reasonable assistance. The McKenzie friend has no personal right to appear as an advocate and no right to address the court: R v Bow Country Court; Ex parte Pelling [1999] 4 All ER 751 at 758–9; [1999] 1 WLR 1807 at 1824–5 ; Damjanovic v Maley (2002) 55 NSWLR 149; 195 ALR 256; [2002] NSWCA 230; BC200203991 ; though the court retains a discretion to grant leave in an appropriate case: see [7.1.5] . Moreover, the court retains a discretion to prevent a person from continuing to act as a McKenzie friend. Normally the “overriding purpose” will require the favourable exercise of that discretion where there is a real prospect that the litigant’s ability to conduct the proceedings will be enhanced by the prospect of assistance, even if the litigant cannot demonstrate any actual personal incapacity or disadvantage: Re H [2002] 1 FLR 39; Re O, W, W-R [2006] Fam 1; [2005] 3 WLR 1191 . Conversely the discretion may be exercised to exclude assistance if the “friend” is indirectly controlling the litigation or is otherwise acting contrary to the interests of the litigant or to the efficient administration of justice: Paragon Finance Plc v Noueiri [2001] 1 WLR 2357 . (Compare KSM Transport Services Pty Ltd v Gregory’s Transport Pty Ltd [2003] NSWSC 901; BC200305869 at [20] where it was questioned whether the use of a McKenzie friend did require formal leave). Judicial concern has prompted comments highly critical of the practice of permitting the assistance of a McKenzie friend, especially in criminal matters: Re B [1981] 2 NSWLR 372 at 385, 405 ; R v Smith [1982] 2 NSWLR 608 at 613 . See further: Mildren, “The problem of unrepresented litigants in criminal trials” (1999) 19 Aust Bar Rev 30; Byrne and Leggat, “Litigants in person — procedural and ethical issues for barristers” (1999) 19 Aust Bar Rev 41. In Teese v State Bank of New South Wales [2002] NSWCA 219; BC200203807 , it was suggested that an application for the assistance of a McKenzie friend should be made before the substantive hearing of the proceedings. In Kelly v Mosman Municipal Council (2010) 178 LGERA 136; [2010] NSWCA 370; BC201009839 a McKenzie friend was allowed for purpose of hearing but it was held to be inappropriate to grant leave to appear as McKenzie friend on an indefinite basis. A litigant cannot, by power of attorney, confer on another person the right to appear in court as his or her lay advocate: Gregory v Turner [2003] 2 All ER 1114; [2003] 1 WLR 1149 ; Giniotis v Farrugia (NSWCA, Kirby P, 19 August 1985, unreported, BC8500603).

level.toc-caption: [7.1.32] Litigants in person and partial representation

heading.title: Litigants in person and partial representation

p.text: A litigant has no entitlement to address or otherwise conduct the case when they are legally represented in the proceedings. A litigant cannot circumvent this prohibition by either limiting the scope of the lawyer’s retainer or by terminating the retainer in the course of the proceedings: Malouf v Malouf (2006) 65 NSWLR 449; [2006] NSWCA 83; BC200602697 at [170]–[179] (appellant represented for some grounds of appeal — legal practitioner unwilling to accept professional responsibility for other grounds — litigant in person presenting submissions on those grounds).
Legislation cited in [7.1.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 21.10, 21.11, rr 34.1, 34.2, r 7.3.

An unrepresented litigant requires leave under r 7.3 to obtain the issue of a subpoena. The requirement for leave does not restrict an unrepresented litigant’s entitlement to require the production of documents referred to in pleadings (see rr 21.10 and 21.11 ) or to issue a notice to produce to another party in the proceedings (see rr 34.1 and 34.2 ).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 7.2] r 7.2 Affidavit as to authority to commence and carry on proceedings in Supreme Court or District Court (cf SCR Part 4, rule 4A, Part 11, rule 1A)

leg:heading.title: Affidavit as to authority to commence and carry on proceedings in Supreme Court or District Court (cf SCR Part 4, rule 4A, Part 11, rule 1A)

p.text: A person who commences or carries on proceedings in the Supreme Court or District Court:
as the director of a company within the meaning of the Corporations Act 2001 of the Commonwealth, or

as the authorised officer of a corporation (other than a company within the meaning of the Corporations Act 2001 of the Commonwealth), must file with the originating process, notice of appearance or defence, as the case may be, an affidavit as to his or her authority to act in that capacity, together with a copy of the instrument evidencing that authority.
The affidavit made by the director of a company within the meaning of the Corporations Act 2001 of the Commonwealth must contain:
a statement to the effect that:
the director is a director of the company, and

the director has been authorised by a resolution of the directors duly passed at a meeting of directors held on a specified date (which must not be earlier than 21 days before the date of the affidavit) to commence and carry on the proceedings, as the case requires, and
the authority has not been revoked, and
the director is aware that he or she may be liable to pay some or all of the costs of the proceedings, or
a statement to the effect that:
the director is the managing or governing director of the company and has authority to exercise the powers of the directors, and
the director is aware that he or she may be liable to pay some or all of the costs of the proceedings.
The affidavit made by the authorised officer of a corporation (other than a company within the meaning of the Corporations Act 2001 of the Commonwealth) must contain a statement to the effect that:
the officer is the holder of a specified office within the corporation, and
the officer has been authorised by the corporation to commence and carry on the proceedings, and
the authority has not been revoked, and
the officer is aware that he or she may be liable to pay some or all of the costs of the proceedings.

level.toc-caption: [7.2.5] Appearance by corporations — directors and authorised officers

heading.title: Appearance by corporations — directors and authorised officers

p.text: A company cannot commence proceedings “in person”: Hubbard Association of Scientologists International v Anderson [1972] VR 340 at 341 . Consequently whilst a company may conduct any proceedings by a retained solicitor, it can only conduct proceedings by a director, authorised officer or employee in the circumstances permitted by UCPR r 7.1(2).

In the Supreme Court, a company that is a corporation for the purposes of the Corporations Act 2001 can conduct proceedings by a director only if both the company and the director are proper plaintiffs in the proceedings: UCPR rr 7.2(a) and 7.1(3): Connectland Pty Ltd v Porthaven Pty Ltd [2011] NSWSC 616; BC201104687 (director cannot conduct proceedings to set aside a statutory demand). In the District Court a corporation may both commence, and defend, proceedings by a director. In the Local Court an authorised officer may commence and conduct proceedings on behalf of a corporation. In all cases the director or officer must be actually authorised by the corporation to conduct the proceedings on its behalf: see Club Flotilla (Pacific Palms) Ltd v Isherwood (1987) 12 ACLR 387; 5 ACLC 1027; BC8701101 (directors, but not the company secretary, may authorise proceedings).

Where a director conducts proceedings under the present rule, adverse costs orders may be made against them personally: Yang v Hypec Electronics Pty Ltd (in liq) [2003] NSWCA 181; BC200305084 ; Access Services Group Pty Ltd v McLoughlin (2006) 201 FLR 16; 57 ACSR 725; [2006] NSWSC 532; BC200604077 (but see May v Christodoulou [2011] NSWCA 75; BC201101949 at [53] and [54] — that under the UCPR since August 2005 the power only derives from CPA s 98 and is, consequently, limited).

Proceedings irregularly commenced for a company by a director are nevertheless valid. In the absence of evidence of substantial irremediable injustice (see Corporations Act 1322) they are able to be continued, albeit in compliance with the rules: In the matter of Re TQC International Pty Ltd [2010] NSWSC 1260; BC201008056 ; JSBG Developments Pty Ltd v Kozlowski (2009) 75 NSWLR 745; 236 FLR 288; [2009] NSWSC 1128; BC200909671 .
Legislation cited in [7.2.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 ss 159.

The permissions conferred by UCPR r 7.1(2) and (3) provide conditional exceptions to the normal practice that a corporation must be represented by a solicitor and cannot conduct litigation in person: Re Education Pty Ltd and the Companies Act 1936–1960 [1963] NSWR 1340; (1963) 80 WN (NSW) 497 ; Frinton & Walton Urban District Council v Walton & District Sand & Mineral Co Ltd [1938] 1 All ER 649 ; Tritonia Ltd v Equity & Law Life Assurance Society [1943] AC 584 ; Free Wheel Co Ltd v Inglis Brothers (1903) 23 NZLR 309 at 318 ; Re GJ Mannix Ltd [1984] 1 NZLR 309 at 314 ; Battle v Irish Art Promotion Centre Ltd [1968] IR 252 ; Hubbard Assn of Scientologists International v Anderson [1972] VR 340 ; Molnar Engineering Pty Ltd v Herald & Weekly Times Ltd (1984) 1 FCR 455 ; Bay Marine Pty Ltd v Clayton Country Properties Pty Ltd (1986) 8 NSWLR 104; 11 ACLR 326 ; Jiwira Pty Ltd v Primary Industry Bank of Australia Ltd (NSWSC, McLaughlin M, 17 February 1995, unreported, BC9504254) (the normal rule applied even if a barrister could act without the intervention of an instructing solicitor). This requirement is not merely technical. The court must be satisfied that a person who purports to act on behalf of a corporation can commit it to enforceable obligations in the conduct of proceedings: Bay Marine, above, NSWLR at 105–6, 113. Although the suggestion has been made that ss 159 , 160, 161 and 162 of the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) permit authorised officers of a company to appear in court (Peters v Australian Institute of Food Science & Technology Ltd (1986) 10 ACLR 547 ), that proposition has been doubted in the Court of Appeal: Bay Marine, above, NSWLR at 110–11 per Samuels J; cf Kirby P at 109.

Any court is likely to have an incidental power to permit a company to carry on proceedings without a solicitor: Bay Marine, above, NSWLR at 108–9, 111, 113; O'Toole v Scott [1965] AC 939; [1966] ALR 821; (1965) 39 ALJR 15; [1965] 2 All ER 240 . The power may also arise under CPA s 14. But in either case, circumstances would have to be particularly out of the ordinary to justify the exercise of any such power, and especially in the absence of evidence of compliance with the present rule: Bay Marine, above, NSWLR at 107; see also Access Services Group Pty Ltd v McLoughlin (2006) 201 FLR 16; 57 ACSR 725; [2006] NSWSC 532; BC200604077 at [10]ff (application to set aside statutory demand — no exceptional circumstances).

Conversely, even where the requirements of the rules have been satisfied the court may still have an inherent or incidental power to disallow appearance by a particular director. However, having regard to the terms of the rule, exceptional circumstances would be required: Manitowoc Crane Group Asia Pte limited v Preston Erection Pty Ltd [2004] NSWSC 1141 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 7.3] r 7.3 Issue of subpoena in certain circumstances requires leave (cf SCR Part 66, rule 1A)

leg:heading.title: Issue of subpoena in certain circumstances requires leave (cf SCR Part 66, rule 1A)

p.text: A subpoena may not be issued, except by leave of the court, unless the party at whose request the subpoena is to be issued is represented by a solicitor in the proceedings.
Leave under subrule (1) may be given either generally or in relation to a particular subpoena or subpoenas.
Despite subrule (1), a subpoena may not be issued in relation to proceedings in the Small Claims Division of the Local Court, except by leave of the court, in any circumstances.
[subr (3) am Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 2[1], effective 6 July 2009]

level.toc-caption: [7.3.5] Subpoenas in the Small Claims Division

heading.title: Subpoenas in the Small Claims Division

p.text: See commentary at [22,010.25] .

level.toc-caption: [7.3.10] Unrepresented parties require leave to issue subpoena

heading.title: Unrepresented parties require leave to issue subpoena

p.text: Unrepresented parties must seek leave of the court before a subpoena may be issued at their request. The subpoenas sought to be issued must be filed at the registry of the Supreme Court together with a statement of written reasons demonstrating the relevance of the documents or evidence sought. The relevant forms are:
Subpoena to produce with subpoena notice and declaration — Form 26A (written reasons should state the relevance of the documents sought from the producing party to proceedings);
Subpoena to attend to give evidence and to produce with subpoena notice and declaration — Form 27A (written reasons should include all the information above).
